title: Can a bad Credit score prevent me from getting a job?
question: I lost my job and may have to file for bankruptcy to get out of debt. Will having a bad credit score prevent me getting another job? What about having a bankruptcy? Will that persuade an employer to not hire me?
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Bankruptcy court,Credit score,Chapter 13 bankruptcy,Credit,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Chapter 13 bankruptcy reorganization plan,Employment,Unemployment compensation
answers:
The answer to all of your questions depends on whether the employer does a financial background check on its candidates. Most employers do not pay that expense if the open position is not a financial or fiduciary based position. For those that do run financial background checks, your filing bankruptcy may be relevant and could be a negative factor in your hiring.

Given the weakness of our economy and the rising unemployment rate, most employers are seeing more and more candidates with your similar history. With bankruptcy filings nearing a record high, employers should not be surprised when considering candidates with a bankruptcy filing in their history. Employers are not legally allowed to discriminate on the basis of bankruptcy but they do it nonetheless.

There are many employers who do not check credit files before hiring. This is particularly true if the job does not involve handling money.

If the job does involve money, it will help to be up front with the potential employer. Let them know the particulars and your plans for the future. They will look more favorably upon you, particularly if you file a Chapter 13 and have a plan to pay off debt, as opposed to filing a Chapter 7.

Whether a bad credit score will affect your ability to get a job will depend on the employment laws of your state, the type of job you're seeking and the policies of your employer. If you're handling money or responsible for property, it is most likely to be a problem. But worry less about the score than about the derogatories that pulled it down. Accounts that show some form of payment or settlement are less damaging that unpaid accounts where liability is still open-ended. Employers are not supposed to discriminate against you because of a bankruptcy, but they do it all the time (legally) because they CAN discriminate based on the derogatories on the accounts that were included in the bankruptcy. It seems a distinction without a difference, but it is what it is.

With extended unemployment compensation having been cut off, the pool of potential employees with spotless credit is going to get a lot smaller. Job hunting will be affected less and less by such problems, assuming we return to anything like full employment.

Consider a prospective employer's position. No employer relishes the thought of hiring an employee that is obviously going to be garnished as soon as they are hired. That's a lot of work for the payroll department. So a prospective hire that has already handled their debt through Bankruptcy Court looks like a much more responsible bet. Good luck in the job market.
